SL1 was decent so how come the sequal was this bad? The biggest flaw of SL2 is the developers forcing unnecessary realism into point-and-click, again. Like in Syberia having to watch the unskippable stairwalking animations... The graphics are worse compared to previous game but you'll get used to it and then it looks quite nice. The voice acting is horrible, Paloma Hernandez in particular. The story presentation is sometimes confuzing. Here are the cons:

1. Time limit in some puzzles: solve this riddle in a few minutes or die, and try again. Pray that you've got all the needed clues before the clock starts ticking. And I tell you: it will get worse later in the game because suddenly there's a♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ of these time limited scenarios. And because characters move smoothly like a reversing logtruck so you waste most of your precious time trying to get where you want.

2. RPG-styled inventory micromanagement. The mother of gamebreakers in history of point-and-click. You have limited amount of slots in inventory, therefore you sometimes have to drop some items into containers and get them later. And how fun is the backtracing with Microids snail-paced, clunky-moving unresponding controls. Oh by the way those containers are not 'linked', so if you leave an item in a container you won't find it in any other container. For the sake of realism of course.

3. Character relative camera. It follows every, I mean EVERY move of the character. So when she's idling the camera wobbles side to side along her idling animation. I remember some the other game from Microids/GameCo which had this same feature and it was infuriating.

4. At least on my computer the game sometimes ran ok but sometimes crashed for no reason every 5 min when investigating objects. Remember to save often.

5. You die constantly in the end game if you don't know what to do fast enough. But thinking of the characters in particular, who the heck cares?

At least I played this piece of art through and in conclusion: SL2 managed to violate every reason there is for me to play point and click.

Their are a few positives. The music is good in addition to the atmosphere, and for a game in this genre, its actually pretty long.

Overall, their are plenty of other games to play than this one. The first game although flawed, is better.

reviewText:
Short version: 23%Do you know those cheap, low-rated, horrible direct-to-video sequels that often have nothing to do with the original films apart from using their title? Still Life 2 is the point ‘n’ click equivalent of those.

Long version: While it’d be hard to say Still Life was the most original adventure game ever made with its obvious Jack the Ripper storyline, at least it had its own memorable style both with the cast and the scenery, and it also had two interesting plot lines with almost perfect pacing.
Still Life 2 just feels like as if someone found a rejected script for the never-made Kiss the Girls 2, changed the title, spent a couple hundred dollars on development, and hoped that somebody will eventually buy it.

Everything in this game is bland. The environment is cheap 3D with bad camera movement and boring brown textures instead of the unique art déco scenery that gave the first game its distinct atmosphere. The cast was replaced with a bunch of interns doing their first voice acting job. The characters are Z-grade thriller cut-outs without any memorable features.

The story is just boring. Surprisingly boring for a thriller about a serial killer who holds a known television reporter hostage in a mansion stolen right from a Saw movie, with the most ludicrous traps planted everywhere. You have zero incentive to progress, especially when you are presented with the one-hour clue-gathering tasks that repeat the same actions over two dozen times.
And as a final insult, there are the twists. They just keep going and going: every time you think you finally reached the end, you suddenly discover a new part of this endless maze of a mansion with another impossible hurdle to overcome by a set of illogical and unintuitive puzzles that always manage to involve inventory management busywork. And at every new twist you seriously question your decision to ever start this game, which is probably one of the biggest mistakes anyone can make.

A genuine piece of art marred by poor delivery and execution. Still Life 2 remains unpolished over its predecessor continuing its lack of high resolution support. The story is involved and engaging, yet takes twists to the extreme and often ends up being more comedic than dramatic.

There is significantly more user interaction than the original Still Life sometimes to the point of being overwhelming. The inventory system definitely takes a step backwards and the timed events remove the typical casual point-and-click play style.

Overall, I found it to be painfully meticulous resulting in puzzle fatigue and ultimately causing me to resort to a walkthrough rather than actually wanting to legitimately solve the puzzles. Even after finishing it, I don't feel a sense of accomplishment, but I am glad it's over.

reviewText:
Since 2005, I had been dying to play the sequel to Still Life. It ended with a cliffhanging ending that was painful to not know the identity of the Masked Killer. I got worried when I heard rumors about Still Life 2's cancellation soon after that but now that I have finally completed the game, I wish it stayed lost in the abyss.

Still Life 2 is a major disappointment on so many levels. The first thing is the quality itself; the character would stutter when it collides with an object, the gameplay is so stiff and the the lighting is lacking. As you play, you will feel disoriented interacting with the environment because the point n click mechanics is so wonky like it goes against your gameplay instinct. It's very hard to explain.

I'm especially disappointed with the visuals as it looks nothing like the original. Although it is commendable that they switched from pre-rendered backgrounds to full 3D but I wish they had stuck with the former even though it may look outdated. There is absolutely no facial expression or motion capture in  the characters and the voice acting is really bad. It's so silly to see a bunch of people standing idly like toy soldiers.

The puzzles are not that fun either. They are not as cryptic as that stupid lockpicking and cooking puzzles in Still Life 1 but in here, there's so little hints and to make matters worse, there's time limit! This goes against the rules of Adventure games. I find myself looking at walkthroughs, which I didn't do in the previous game.

The only word I can describe Still Life 2 is suck." The overall experience was just painful and a huge letdown. The only reason why I presevered to complete it was to find out who the Masked Killer was but when he did reveal himself

That's right. You control 2 characters; one is Agent Vic McPherson of course and the other is some scumbag reporter that has nothing to do with the Masked Killer plotline.\n\nCompleting the game really left a bad taste in my mouth. Gameplay compared to the first one is more enjoyable for me. Both are great, but here you have more puzzles-riddles and you get timed sequences that add to the experience.

All in all the game is an amazing thriller-adventure. You expect danger whenever you open a door, especially in the second half part of the game. Some bugs here and there but only twice i had to load (character refuse to move).

9/10 for me and a worthy sequel to first one. Too bad the series ended there...

reviewText:
1) You should have played Still Life 1 first!!!

2) Save as much as possible cause you can die and this game has some countdown-action parts.

3) You inventory is limited, which means you have to outsource stuff in special boxes for extra space. This means if you do not have the correct item with you in an time based action sequence you will may fail.

4) Use a walkthough!!! Really!!! It will not totally destroy the story, it will save your gaming fun. This game will also give you only 1 chance for the good ending sequence. If you fail you will get no new chance cause the game will destroy your savegames then. YES, you haven't missread that!!!

About the game: You play again as Victoria McPherson, your FBI Test Kit is much more detailed with 3D Scanner, USB Stick for hacking and all the other stuff you need to be an FBI Agent. You will also play as the latest victim of the murder, Paloma Hernandez, a journalist working on the story of the killer.

The game totally reminds me of movies like SAW, the killer is playing games with you and it's very hard to win.

The story is great, so many twists. You think you have the murder and then it will totally surprise you. Over and over again...

Biggest Negativ: If you miss just one little evidence, a finger print or a little blood spatter the game will not continue even if it isn't really important for the story. And there are many of them! That's why you should play with walkthrough.

All in one: Good game but not as good as Still Life 1 was. 7/10

Well... Where do I begin?

I pre-ordered this game when it first came out, many years ago, after being totaly hooked on Still Life (which in my humble opinion is one of the best adventure games EVER made).

I will start with the aspects of this game that I enjoyed:
* Finding out who the killer was from the first Still Life
* The forensic clue finding and analysing element of this game
* Following the story of Vic after liking her in the first game
* The similar game play as with the first game
* The ability to create different endings dependant on the choices you make

Things I was not keen on:

* The story line/plot was overly elaborate which resulted in the game being unbelievable and slightly cheesy, especially towards the ending.

reviewText:
I do recommend both games. I usually like these types of games, although, this time I have to say so with a reservation.

It's a point and click game wrapped around a murder mystery. So, not a new idea nor much of horror to begin with. Yet I found this game very creepy and much more depressing than some survival horror games I have played. Maybe it's because this game doesn't involve any kind of mystical or supernatural elements or even messed up psychological state the protagonist would be in. It's just the pure pathological psychotism and visceral sadism of the story that gets me. It's not the fantastical unrealistic kind of evil, it's something that could actually happen. And that the story is revealed and told in such a minimalist way, it actually makes it worse than any gory jump scare ever would.

One good sign of a game is that it leaves you thinking, leaves you with mixed emotions..

This time I'm not all too sure. It still gives me the creeps.
